reviewText:
If anybody else had trouble to start up this game like me then here is what i did to fix it.

1) If steam remains stuck in preparing to launch. Make sure the game is installed on the same hard drive as steam. Usually the C drive.

2) If the game flickers. Go to your steamapps/common folder then safecracker2. In config AND STEAM_config files change bFullScreen=1 TO bFullScreen=0 and save.

3) I also had the game freeze on a black screen. To resolve this in my case i went to Nvidia control panel, manage 3d settings. Safecracker2 then manually turn Antialiasing mode to off. That solved all my issues and yes it was worth it.

I love games that put your brain to the test and Safecracker certainly did that!
The puzzles were varied enough to keep the whole experience interesting. It was nice having a subtle story behind it too, as it gave it more meaning. I would recommend this game to those who enjoy solving puzzles and feel rewarded when they finally crack a safe.

Took around 6 hours to complete and i found having a pen and paper handy helped :)

reviewText:
This is not a game for everybody, but I LOVED it. As other reviewers are saying, it won't hold your hand--the puzzles are pretty darn difficult and usually don't explain themselves. But that's the appeal for me. It's like I really get to be a detective in some movie or something, and I have nothing but my wits to go on. The downside to the difficulty is, of course, you WILL get frustrated from time to time--pretty often, in fact, so if you don't like scratching your head too much, this isn't your game. But the difficulty of the puzzles and having to figure out even what you have to do to figure them out means that you get a huge rush from solving them. Not joking, the satisfaction of solving these things is great, makes ya feel like an extra-special clever lil cupcake. Beating the game made me feel like a genius.

I do want to point out, someof the puzzles require you to give up on the room you're working through, try another route, then come back when you've gained a clue or insight from somewhere later in the game. If you have to come back to a puzzle, it doesn't mean you've failed, and you're probably doing what you're actually supposed to by saving it for later.

The problems I did have were mostly interface ones: when you do get a verbal clue from your character, it is only ever said once, and there's no way of it being logged in a Notes menu or anything, so if you go AFK for a minute at the wrong time or don't have your sound turned on, you can miss the hint completely. The hints usually aren't going to be crucial to solving a given puzzle, though. Also, I wished it was easier to move around the house; because the game is a point-and-click, you walk down hallways by clicking your mouse in the direction you want to go, and the screen changes to the part of the room you're in as you move. There is a map in your menu that gets marked off when you solve the puzzle in that room, and I wanted to be able to fast-travel" or something similar by clicking on the room I wanted to go to

First of all - yeah, when I first started this game on my Win7 it had a twitchy picture and was virtually unplayable. My solution was to run it in windowed mode (via config file). Not a perfect way, but I've hardly seen any downsides.
Apart from that - don't get it wrong. It is a puzzle-puzzle game. It's short, it has next to nonexistent plot (which at the ending seems not only nearly nonexistent, but unnecessary as well). All in all - guys, it's not Myst, ok? It's a collection of assorted puzzles in a comfy environment. It will be a mistake to see it as anything but.
And so, the cornerstone of the game - puzzles. Puzzles are mostly really good. Some are quite inventive, some do a sort of unexpected play on widely known puzzle (like a famous pipeline puzzle with restricted movements, for instances) But, well, at the same time couple of puzzles are really dumb, while others just require decent amount of mix-and-match, which is not that fun. And of course, it can't be unmentioned - The confederate Cipher wheel WAS NOT used this way. It's a vanilla Caesar cipher in game! Come on, son! The whole point of cipher wheel is to scramble the letter statistics. Why can't you've used the proper codeword instead?! Oh, and a 6 moving pins puzzle is WAY too easy for it's own idea.
That said, other puzzles are fairly decent and inventive, though I've actually managed to solve 2 or 3 of them by semi-random clicking.
So there you have it, it's a compendium of puzzles set in a nicely drawn decor. Some are genuinely good, some are fairly stupid, some are unnecessary hard (that damn broken lock!). So pick it up on a sale cheap, go have your grey matter for a swing for an evening or two, but be cautious whether you'd manage to run it properly on a modern system.

reviewText:
The basic story follows a safe cracking specialist hired to find the will of a multi millionaire, thought to be hidden somewhere in his mansion. Seems the gramps was quite eccentric, to say the least, loved puzzles and safe machines, and decided not to inform anyone which of his 5 family members is the heir -- no surprise they'll do anything to have the will found!

It's a short game (2-3 hours) but really well made, the high production level is evident in the good graphics, not to mention the amount of well-designed and non-trivial puzzles.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=23653309

The environment is limited to the inside of a giant mansion, with dozens of rooms spread over 3 levels and an enclosed garden. Every room is decorated to the highest level of detail -- papers scattered on a desk, chairs, paintings, different clothes in a walk-in wardrobe, sofas with cushions -- everything you'd expect in a mansion belonging to a well-educated and intelligent yet somewhat eccentric millionaire.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=41225340

The puzzles share the same level of detail, the various boxes are engraved with different patterns, the wooden surfaces lacquered and polished to a high sheen, golden keys with intricate handles -- there's too much to list it all, and that'd spoil the fun. But the presentation of the boxes are not the only selling point of Safecracker - the puzzle are quite tricky to solve, some require a flexible mind, some a good pair of eyes and a keen observation sense. There's ciphers, hidden keys, sliding blocks, lasers, wire boxes, and much more!
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=83427764

I can't really find any reason not to recommend this game, especially since it's not expensive, at £4.49. It looks great, gives your brain a good workout, and there's no need to set aside a whole month to finish it.

Assuming it runs well on your machine, this game is actually quite fun. But before you get the game, a few things should be stated.
1. You do not roam freely around the house you have to explore. Instead, you click your way to waypoints, much like with Google Street View, and then have a 360° picture of your surroundings. Interactive objects, such as one of the many safes, can be simply clicked on.
2. The puzzles are hard, but (mostly) fair. I recommend having at least 3 sheets of paper and a pen beside you when playing. They will definitely come in handy. One thing to keep in mind is that you will not be told what is the expexted solution of the puzzles. Had to look up two of them because I simply didn't get what I was supposed to do.
3. A few of the puzzles are actually well-known. I immediately knew the answer to one of them simply because I've solved the exact same puzzle in another game and recognized the patterns of quite a few of them (  the water canister puzzle with 8, 5 and 3 units of water, if anyone's wondering  ). Can be interpreted as positive or negative.
4. The story is, well, meh. I can see the devs really did put quite a bit of thought in how to fit the puzzles into the story, and did actually do a decent job at it, but the game is, in my opinion, mostly about the puzzles.
5. The ending leaves you slightly unsatisfied. No cut-scene or anything, just a text-based decision to make with a text-based outcome. Seems like the devs didn't want to put a lot more effort into creating an ending.

Nonetheless, it was a lot of fun while it lasted. The overall atmosphere is undisturbed and somehow inspirational, too. The music is sometimes a bit dark, but doesn't feel too displaced in any situation.
What I found strange was that the game wouldn't start if I switched the Steam language setting for this specific game to English. I had to play it in German - not much of a problem for me, but still kind of off-setting.
Oh, and one more thing ... if you're a diehard fan of smooth graphics with lots of effort in lighting and whatsoever, move on. This game clearly isn't for you.

In total, I'd give the game a solid 7/10. Worth buying if you like to spend a few relaxed hours with tackling some well designed puzzles, especially at this low price.

The story exists purely a motivational device to send you around a house solving puzzles to break into safes. The graphics, voice acting, dialogue, and music are both inoffensive and do not deter from the main focus: the puzzles.

The puzzles are a good variety of really great logic-based problems: no random guessing, time limits, insta-death, etc. Some cannot be solved immediately, as you need a component, hint, or mapping, that is generated from another puzzle's solution, but after a while I began to recognize when that was the case.
Tip: Right click to open your inventory and to see a map of the mansion indicating unsolved puzzles.

I would NOT recommend this game to someone who hasn't tried their hand at logic/puzzle games before, as it would probably be a very frustrating experience - the hand-holding/hint system is essentially non-existent.
